content.text: A business model explains how a company earns money. It describes what the company sells, who its customers are, how it delivers products or services, and how it earns profit after costs.
For investors, understanding the business model is the first step of fundamental analysis. Numbers only make sense when you understand what the company actually does in real life.
Why Business Model Matters for Investing
A strong business model allows consistent profits, pricing power, and long-term growth. Weak business models depend heavily on market conditions or discounts to survive.
Even if current profits are high, a fragile business model may collapse when competition increases or regulations change.
How to Analyze a Business Model
Study the product, target customers, revenue sources, cost structure, and customer retention. Ask whether customers will keep buying and whether competitors can easily copy the product.
Example: A subscription software company has recurring revenue, while a construction company earns only when new projects are available.
